    Table of Contents
      What is Adobe Target?
      Key Concepts
      How Adobe Target Works
      Why Use Adobe Target?
      Adobe Target and Tealium
    Adobe Target
      Adobe Target helps visually create and manage A/B tests and rules-based targeting activities. It can be used for marketing offers, personalization and UX testing; allowing marketers to figure out which of the offers, experiences & messages are truly engaging the customers. It includes a user interface, built-in best practices, and robust optimization tools for following site visitors.
    Key Concepts
      Activity: determines the experiences a site visitor might encounter.
      For example, you might design an activity that tests two different landing pages, one that highlights information about women's summer shoes, and one that highlights more general summer apparel. The activity determines the conditions that control when each of these landing pages appears, and the metrics that determine which page is more successful. The activity is configured to start and end when specific conditions are met, such as between specific dates, or to start when the activity is approved and to end when it is deactivated.
    Key Concepts
      Experiences: defines the content that displays on your page, as well as other page elements, such as links.
    Key Concepts
      Offers: the content displayed on your webpages during campaigns or activities.
      When you test your webpages, you measure the success of each experience with different offers in your locations. An offer can contain different types of content, including: image, text, html, link, button. For example, a webpage might display either of two offers, depending on whether the visitor has been to your site before. An experience determines which content displays when particular conditions are met.
    Key Concepts
      Audiences: define the target for your activity and are used anywhere where targeting is available.
    Key Concepts (cont'd)
      A/B Testing: an activity type that compares two or more versions of your Web site content to see which version best improves your conversions during a pre-specified test period.
      An A/B test (sometimes referred to as an A/B...N test) compares two or more versions of a web site's content to see which best lifts conversions, sales, or other identified metrics. Use an A/B test to compare changes to a page against the default page design to determine which experience produces the best results.
    How Adobe Target Works
      Adobe Target integrates with websites by means of one of two JavaScript libraries: at.js or mbox.js
      The at.js library is the new implementation library for Target. The at.js library improves page-load times for web implementations and provides better implementation options for single-page applications.
      The mbox.js library is the legacy implementation library for Target. The mbox.js library is still supported, but there will be no feature updates.
      Mbox.js calls another JavaScript file, target.js. Target.js is hosted by Adobe, automatically updated by Adobe and is responsible for DOM Manipulation.
    How Adobe Target Works (cont'd)
      Each time a visitor requests a page that has been optimized for Target, a request is sent to the targeting system to determine what content to serve to a visitor. This process occurs in real-time — every time a page is loaded, a request for the content is made and fulfilled by the system. The content is governed by the rules of marketer-controlled activities and experiences and is targeted to the individual site visitor. Content is served that each site visitor is most likely to respond to, interact with, and ultimately purchase, to maximize response rates, acquisition rates, and revenue.
      You must reference the Target JavaScript library file on every page on your site.
    Why Use Adobe Target?
      The main business drivers behind the use of Test & Target at this point is conversion optimization. It provides intuitive test reports based on different segments such as new and returning users. The tool can be plugged-in with other marketing cloud products as well as other third party marketing tools.
    Why Use Adobe Target (cont'd)?
      Ability to execute multiple tests simultaneously and to segment traffic to particular tests makes target highly scalable.
      Integration with other tools through plug-ins saves a lot of time and resources.
      Target audiences by device type, operating system, screen size, geolocation, or profile (whether anonymous or registered) to deliver the best experience.
      Easily create, test, and manage automated recommendations for promotions such as cross-sell or upsell within mobile apps or sites.
    Adobe Target and TiQ
    The mbox
      An mbox is a “marketing box,” which is an area on a web page used by Adobe Target to show different content to visitors in a campaign. Marketers can replace blocks of content in the mbox with dynamic content that they’ve created in Adobe Target. The content displayed inside an mbox during a campaign is called an offer.
      Adobe Target has two methods that can be used to modify content: Place Regional mboxes in pages in the exact locations where content will be modified. Place a Global mbox create statement in the page and define all logic within the Adobe TnT interface as to which content will be modified.
    Adobe Target and TiQ (cont'd)
    Using Global mbox with utag.sync.js
      The Global mbox approach is a synchronous implementation, while keeping the rest of the Tealium implementation asynchronous to mitigate risk. Once set up, within the utag.sync.js you will have pasted the mbox.js file and added a small snippet, or two small snippets, to call mboxCreate().
    Adobe Target and TiQ (cont'd)
    Using Global mbox with utag.sync.js
      Enable utag.sync
      Code utag.sync into head of page
      Download mbox.js
      Locally host mbox.js
      Configure utag.sync
    Adobe Target and TiQ (cont'd)
    What is Flicker?
      Flicker is the occurrence of default content being momentarily displayed to the visitor before it is replaced with the content you intended to show the visitor, making it seem to the visitor that the content flickered. Visitors can sometimes interpret flicker as a problem with the site, potentially causing the visitor to lose confidence in the site or brand. Flicker can also cause visitor dissatisfaction if, for example, they see a discount they like "flicker away" to be replaced with a lesser discount. Flicker is a symptom of encountering a delay in loading the content displayed, also called "tests", asynchronously.
    Adobe Target and TiQ (cont'd)
    Flicker Free
      Tealium supports both asynchronous and synchronous versions of the Adobe Target tag. The asynchronous version is recommended. However, if you choose to load your tests synchronously, you will not see flicker occur. However, loading content synchronously means that the entire page must wait to receive that content before it parses and displays the rest of the page.
      Asynchronous loading circumvents the issue of unavailable content halting page load because the browser continues to load the rest of the page while it waits for the pending content. However, if there is a long enough delay between the browser encountering the offer on the page and retrieving the offer's content, visitors may briefly see the default content. This is the flicker phenomenon.
    Adobe Target and TiQ (cont'd)
    Flicker Free: First Approach
      Eliminate flicker by taking Adobe Target module and placing within utag.sync. When the page loads, the browser will encounter the utag.sync.js file which sets the CSS visibility property of to "hidden". The content is not removed, but the browser will not render it. The layout dimensions of the hidden content are preserved, so the layout of your page is not deformed. To a visitor it will appear as though the section where the content would be displayed is blank instead. There is no flicker.
    Adobe Target and TiQ (cont'd)
    Flicker Free: Second Approach
      The Adobe Target Content Modification extension is used with the Adobe Target tag to change the content of an HTML element and can be used to show A/B content based on a condition.The synchronous load does not use the extension.
      To implement extension, set DOM ID and mbox id. Tealium will inject this extension code into utag.sync file. Need to delete fields and republish. Tealium will continue to inject in utag.sync. Scope to Adobe Target tag.
      After you have enabled the publish setting, you must re-publish your profile. Republishing generates the utag.sync.js file and pushes it onto Tealium's multi-CDN infrastructure. If you do not publish after enabling the publish setting, any pa ge that references that utag.sync.js file will not be able to find it, potentially causing page load failure.
    Adobe Target and TiQ (cont'd)
    Target & Experience Cloud ID
      If you’re using Adobe Experience Cloud ID service (Adobe Analytics Visitor API), Cloud ID needs to be called first. If using Adobe Target Tag and Cloud ID service tag, the experience cloud is put on top and loaded first because of its settings.
      If adobe target module is in utag.sync, then visitor API needs to be loaded before in utag.sync. Use that as opposed to using experience cloud ID tag.
    Directions
      Set up a localhost server with an alias
      Log into TiQ and set up a Google Analytics tag (analytics.js)
      On your localhost webpage, use Google Analytics to trigger a click event on a link

      Code Center

    Setting up GA Tag
      Add GA Tag
      GA Tracking ID and domain name

    GA Event Tracking
      Used Extensions: GA_Click (JS Code) and jQuery onHandler
      Scoped to fire when button/link is clicked
 $("#demo-link").on("click", function() {
        console.log("Handler for .click() called.");
        ga(
          "send",
          "event",
          "details_share",
          "details_share",
          "details_share_click"
        );
      });
    Debugging | Verification
    Chrome DevTools
      The console is your best friend
      utag.js debug mode: document.cookie="utagdb=true"
      Verify events are firing properly
      Verify via Network tab: network log
      Fallback: Check realtime statistics on Analytics account
    AudienceStream
    Exercise #1
      Utilizing https://www.americangirl.com, create a category browser attribute when a visitor has visited a category page five or more times in their lifetime.
    Implementation
      The console is your best friend: verify page_type (UDO)
      Once in AudienceStream, click "Attributes": add attribute - visitor scope
      Create page_type: category "number" attribute: increment category page visits by one
      Create "Category Browser" Badge attribute to be assigned after threshold is met
    AudienceStream
    Exercise #2
      Create a favorite product attribute when a visitor has viewed a product five or more times.
    Implementation
      Create Product SKU "set of strings" attribute
      Create page_type: product "number" attribute to increment page visits by one
      Create "Favorite Product" Badge attribute to be assigned if someone views product five or more times
    Extra Innings
      Can you walk us through how to trigger a basic modal on your webpage?
      We have a DoubleClick Floodlight tag that we only want to fire once per session. Is there a way to do this in Tealium?
      Create an audience based off of information available to the site and explain what you would use this audience for.
    Triggering a basic modal
    Walk Through
      Once in TiQ, add Modal Offer Extension
      Block modal from firing on DOM Ready
      Add JavaScript Code Extension
      Add your custom action to website and extension
    Delayed Modal Trigger
    DoubleClick Floodlight Tag
    Fire once per session?
      Tealium now sets a "Session Start" cookie called "utag_main__ss." This is set to "1" on the first page of the visit and "0" on subsequent pages
      Add a Data Source called "utag_main__ss" and set the Type to "First Party Cookie"
      Use this in the Load Rule to check if the cookie equals "1"
      This requires version 4.26 or later of the utag.js file
    Creating an Audience
    Implementation
      Add audience
      Keep parameters simple
      Add connector
    My example
      I created a "Category Browsers" audience for individuals who have viewed a category page five or more times. I'd set up a connector with Facebook Ads and target Category Browsers with advertisements tailored with the products of the category they viewed five or more times (ie, books, dolls, clothing, etc.)
